paragraphs.text: Turkey's red line.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: I remember the days when all Turkish citizens had to love Mustafa Kemal Ataturk
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: From kindergarten to high school, all students had to recite an oath of allegiance every morning at school
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I still can't erase the verses from my mind: "Oh Great Ataturk, who had created our life of today; on the path that you have paved, in the country that you established, I swear to walk incessantly with the purposes that you have set."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Every Turkish citizen had to put their hearts and souls into that oath
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The louder you spoke those words, the better a citizen you were
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those days are not yet ancient history
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The ruling Justice and Development Party (AKP) only abolished this fascist practice in 2013
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was good news
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: some weren't so thrilled
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Pro-Kemalist media attacked the reform package, including many democratic regulations
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: while
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: their columnists harshly criticised the move because Turkey was leaving behind its worship of Ataturk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Red lines
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In the days following the global outrage over the attack on the French satirical newspaper, Charlie Hebdo, many in Turkey seem to have forgotten those days when any criticism of Ataturk was a punishable offence - one that could label you a traitor
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Kemalism is not only an ideology
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: for many Turks, it was akin to religion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Poems depicting Ataturk as a God are evidence of an attempt to impose Kemalism as a religion
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That's why Islam, the religion of the majority of Turkish society, was seen as a threat for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was not enough that Ataturk was beloved by his supporters
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We all had to submit to - and idolise - him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Roland Barthes' famous words would describe what we lived then
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "Fascism is not the prohibition of saying things; it is the obligation to say them."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Cumhuriyet, a leading daily newspaper of the old guard founded in 1924, has always been a symbol of Kemalism since the beginning
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Turkish public were accustomed to their publications attacking Muslims, seeing them as a threat, despising them, or their columnists' pieces insulting Islam
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the other hand, they have always had clear red lines when it came to Kemalism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Cumhuriyet has never given a place to a critique of Ataturk or Kemalism
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: on the contrary
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it has attacked the critics
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Last week, Cumhuriyet announced that it would publish the Charlie Hebdo cartoons in order to defend freedom expression
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In so doing, they attracted a lot of reaction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Of course
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Turkish community, mostly Muslim, was dissatisfied with the daily's decision
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they do not consider the insulting of religions as a manifestation of freedom of speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Some say the move was a provocation - or reckless at least
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the majority have regarded the decision as hypocritical
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Critics on social media or even conventional media pointed out their intolerance for any criticism of Ataturk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the daily exaggerated the responses, chose to sail under false colours
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and pictured the insults and the mockery against the publication as an attack on free speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Freedom of speech
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Islamists protested against the paper and its decision
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: nothing happened
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The police did pay a visit to the printing house
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there were no restrictions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The government took precautions against any possible attacks on the daily
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they portrayed the situation as if they were under siege
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Charlie Hebdo is known as a satirical newspaper
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: which is against any authority, any halidom or any individual or group claiming supremacy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Even if we accept this- and I personally don't agree as we are familiar with Charlie Hebdo's double standards insofar as Israel- Cumhuriyet or other Kemalist publications in Turkey are certainly in no position to defend the values of freedom of speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they have zero tolerance for any negative words of their idol, Ataturk
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: On the same day, the Islamist newspaper Yeni Akit's Istanbul office was attacked with stones and eggs during a protest against its publication of beaten images of Ataturk
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: No so-called "freedom of speech" defenders who supported the publication of Charlie Hebdo caricatures, condemned the attack
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Gulenist media figures who introduced themselves as Muslims announced their support for Cumhuriyet for the sake of freedom of speech
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: however they were silent against the attack against Yeni Akit
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The Gulenist media was against Charlie Hebdo's publishing of insulting images of Prophet Muhammad until 2013 and have always been against any publication criticising their leader, Fethullah Gulen
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Their about-face on Charlie Hebdo is linked to their turn on Islam but criticising Gulen has always been a red line for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: According to Zaman daily columnist Ali Unal, criticising Gulen is tantamount to infidelity and polytheism
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In short
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Kemalists and the Gulenists have their own "gods", or their own "prophets"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Insulting Islam is freedom of speech for them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: you dare to speak against their idols
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it is blasphemy
paragraphs.label: assumption
